tier.item: `It's it (a fruit already discussed) that Kambale bought.'
It's it (a fruit already discussed) that Kambale bought.
b. *Eritunda, mo-n-a-bw-ire Kambale nyi-ti -- ry-o n-a-gul-a.
`The fruit, I told Kambale that it's it that I bought.'
The fruit, I told Kambale that it's it that I bought.
d. eri-tunda ery-o Kambale a-gul-a. (relative, Kinande; Philip Mutaka, p.c.)
eri-tunda ery-o Kambale a-gul-a. (relative, Kinande; Philip Mutaka, p.c.)
The woman chopped wood (with an axe).
At the village arrived a woman.
On the table were put peanuts.
`WOMEN do not chop wood (with an axe).' (compare (3a))
WOMEN do not chop wood (with an axe).' (compare (3a))
No woman danced in the market.
The woman danced in the market.
(37) a. Mo-ba-nyi-bw-ire ba-ti Kambale mo-a-gul-ire eritunda.
`They told me that Kambale bought fruit.' (Kinande)
They told me that Kambale bought fruit.' (Kinande)
b. Mo-n-a-layir-ire Kambale in-di a-gul-e amatunda.
`I convinced Kambale that he should buy fruits.'
I convinced Kambale that he should buy fruits.
(i) Eki-hi ky-o Kambale a-ku-bwir-a a-ti n-a-gul-a?
`What did Kambale tell you that I bought?'
Eki-hi ky-o Kambale a-ku-bwir-a a-ti n-a-gul-a?
What did Kambale tell you that I bought?
`It's a fruit that I gave to a woman.'
It's a fruit that I gave to a woman.
It's fruits that the woman bought.
b. obuli mu-kali; obuli ri-tunda Kinande
`Kambale is speaking with the old people.'
Kambale is speaking with the old people.
(62) a. Aba-syakulu b-o Kambale a-ka-kanay-a na-bo.
`It's old people that Kambale is speaking with.' [Confirm w/ notes]
It's old people that Kambale is speaking with.' [Confirm w/ notes]
Old people are not spoken with.
`I put the leg in the hole.'
I put the leg in the hole.
b. Kambale a-seng-er-a omwami y'- ehilanga. (Kinande)
Kambale packed peanuts for the chief.
`I put the leg in the hole.'
I put the leg in the hole.
b. Kambale a-seng-er-a ehilanga hy'- omwami.
Kambale packed peanuts for the chief.
`It seems that the women have left.'
It seems that the women have left.
The women seem to have left.
`It seems that the women have left.'
It seems that the women have left.
(20) a. Mo-ba-nyi-bw-ire ba-ti Kambale mo-a-gul-ire eritunda.
`They told me that Kambale bought fruit.'
They told me that Kambale bought fruit.
b. Mo-n-a-layir-ire Kambale in-di a-gul-e amatunda.
`I convinced Kambale that he should buy fruits.'
I convinced Kambale that he should buy fruits.
